values.alignmentText: UNESCO biosphere reserves and reefs are pristine, but aging city infrastructure and fuel shortages create periodic pollution spikes in Havana.
Sea-level rise, stronger hurricanes, and saltwater intrusion threaten coastal housing and agriculture, demanding resilient construction and evacuation plans.
Tropical: hot, humid summers; warm winters; pronounced wet/hurricane season.
Outside Havana the air is clean, but aging diesel buses and classic cars can leave city corridors hazy, so indoor air filters help sensitive family members.
Regular hurricane exposure and coastal flooding risk.
Havana days ~27–31 C (81–88 F); humidity rises; rains increase in May [source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Havana#Climate).
Havana days ~31–33 C (88–91 F); very humid; frequent storms; hurricane season (Jun–Nov) [source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Havana#Climate).
Havana days ~27–31 C (81–88 F); peak rains and hurricane risk in Sep–Oct; easing by Nov [source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Havana#Climate).
Havana days ~25–27 C (77–81 F); drier season; cooler nights ~18–20 C (64–68 F) [source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Havana#Climate).
Outstanding beaches and warm Caribbean water; tourism amenities concentrated in hubs.
Warm most of the year; most comfortable late spring through fall.
Lush landscapes, reefs, and scenic valleys; many outdoor options.
Very low in global terms; limited purchasing power.
Low salary levels and limited private sector demand.
Small market; few enterprise roles; public sector dominates.
Niche to non-existent; startup ecosystem constrained.
Rare for non-Cubans; regulatory and policy barriers.
Chronic constraints, sanctions, and shortages; limited growth.
Wi-Fi hotspots require prepaid cards, home broadband rarely exceeds 10–20 Mbps, and power cuts still interrupt remote meetings.
Neighbors prioritize family gatherings and music, yet ration lines and power outages consume hours that would otherwise be downtime.
Detailed alignment analysis is pending further research, so the alignment score remains unknown.
Formal leave policies are still being compiled; alignment scoring is not yet determined.
Typical paid leave expectations for international families remain under review, leaving the score unknown.
Generally slower and community-oriented, especially outside Havana.
Day-to-day scheduling guidance is not yet available for this destination, so the score is unknown.
Weekend routine recommendations are pending additional local interviews, keeping the score unknown.
Strong community bonds and kid-friendly public spaces.
Limited social acceptance and no legal recognition.
Family-centric culture; schools emphasize structure and discipline.
Public areas are social and children are welcomed; infrastructure varies.
Outside a handful of Havana schools tied to foreign embassies, international curricula are scarce, so homeschooling or online programs would fill gaps.
Availability varies; information for foreigners limited.
Citizens can enroll children in círculos infantiles and receive subsidized meals, but staffing and supplies fluctuate.
Foreign families rarely secure subsidized slots without residency; most hire private caregivers informally.
Enrollment is universal with high literacy, yet classroom materials and technology lag due to shortages.
Foreign children may attend public schools but instruction is entirely in Spanish and supplies can be scarce, so most expats seek private tutors.
Only a small set of embassy-linked schools operate in Havana with high fees payable in foreign currency and long waitlists.
Some family benefits; service quality depends on local capacity.
Benefits typically target citizens/residents; unclear extension to foreigners.
Tuition-free higher education for citizens; strong state role.
Limited pathways for non-citizens; Spanish proficiency needed.
More traditional norms persist alongside increased female workforce participation.
Visibility improving but constrained by broader social controls.
Legal frameworks exist but civil liberties environment limits advocacy.
Conventional presentation norms; urban areas somewhat more flexible.
Traditional expectations remain common; gradual shifts in cities.
Music, dance, and historic architecture; vibrant everyday culture.
Spanish dominates government offices and schools; beyond resort zones we would rely on fluent Spanish to manage bureaucracy.
Universal healthcare and education coexist with restrictions on speech and association, leaving progressive reforms tightly state-managed.
Official discourse favors socialist principles; market activity is restricted.
State is secular; religious practice present but not dominant in policy.
Public norms are modest; sex education exists within state systems.
Marriage equality passed in 2022 and Havana hosts Pride events, yet outside urban centers queer families still face gossip and limited legal enforcement.
Welcoming, communal street life; relationships deepen through neighborhoods and schools.
Resilient, proud, and culturally rich; emphasis on solidarity.
Regional outlook shaped by history and geopolitics.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Seen as culturally vibrant but politically isolated.
Music and dance scenes are a major draw; hours vary by locale.
Practical, climate-appropriate attire; expressive in social settings.
Colorful, expressive fashion common; practicality in heat/humidity.
Music, dance, baseball, and community gatherings.
Limited visibility; small informal circles possible.
Globally renowned music traditions and live venues.
Grassroots meetups exist; tech/community groups limited online.
Beaches, reefs, and national parks are accessible from major cities.
One-party socialist state with constrained political pluralism.
Secular state; religion has limited policy influence.
Codified labor rights but independent union activity is restricted.
State-led socialist model; private enterprise tightly managed.
Authoritarian governance entrenched; very limited political freedoms.
State-dominated economy with limited market mechanisms.
Regime stability amid economic volatility and shortages.
State media dominates; restricted independent press.
Messaging emphasizes revolution, sovereignty, and social solidarity.
Broad access to education and healthcare; resource constraints affect quality.
Varies; public expression constrained; limited independent polling.
Difficult to assess transparently; data limited.
Bureaucratic and petty corruption can occur in constrained economies.
Aging housing stock; private rental/ownership options limited for foreigners.
Violent crime relatively uncommon; petty theft in tourist areas.
Preventive care and doctor density are high, yet medicine and equipment shortages require rationing or trips abroad for complex treatment.
Foreigners rely on international clinics priced in hard currency, and evacuations are common for serious care.
State-run daycares operate with low fees yet limited slots and occasional closures tied to shortages, so parents lean on relatives.
Strong community support; state benefits exist but resources are tight.
High literacy and strong foundational education; Spanish-only instruction.
Havana’s buses and colectivos are inexpensive but irregular, so planning family outings requires patience and backup rides.
Centrally planned with limited private activity and dual-currency legacy.
State-centric administration; guidance for foreigners is limited.
Tax burden modelling for the family profile is awaiting reliable data sources, so the alignment score is unknown.
US cards do not work; most transactions require cash or MLC cards loaded via third-country accounts.
Staples are cheap when available, yet imported groceries, internet access, and generator fuel priced in MLC quickly consume remote income.
State pension system exists; adequacy depends on resources.
Retirement expectations for long-term visa holders are still being researched, leaving the score unknown.
Work and residence visas are tightly limited; US citizens typically only qualify for short cultural or humanitarian stays, not long-term relocation.
Cubans are hospitable, yet US sanctions and state scrutiny make long-term settlement impractical for American families.
Temporary residence permits renew yearly and require Cuban family ties or state contracts; independent paths are essentially absent.
Naturalization pathways for foreigners are uncommon and opaque.
Foreign spouses rarely obtain derivative status unless married to Cuban citizens; dependent visas for children are not standard.
Permits require multiple ministry approvals and US sanctions complicate payments, so expect long waits and currency hurdles.
US OFAC rules limit spending, while Cuban authorities can confiscate equipment or revoke permits if regulations shift.

Cuban-born dual nationals are treated as Cuban while in Cuba and must use Cuban passports; practical recognition is limited and subject to local rules [source](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/international-travel/International-Travel-Country-Information-Pages/Cuba.html).
Plan for cash-based living, limited access to foreign banking, and frequent police check-ins on rental addresses.
Only small collectives experiment with games, and export controls plus internet limits make commercial releases nearly impossible.
No widely known commercial studios; activity centered in small teams/academia.
Limited presence; small informal groups more likely than formal communities.
Regulatory and funding barriers; exports and payments complicated by sanctions.
Infrastructure lags; periodic power/internet disruptions; cash-centric payments.

Dangerous extremes are routine, forcing us to track emergency alerts and modify plans multiple times a quarter. Seasonal Weather at 3/10 and Natural Disasters at 3/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for seasonal extremes & variability.

Months of oppressive darkness or bright nights disrupt sleep cycles and make remote work or study harder to sustain. Seasonal Weather at 3/10 and Environment at 6/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for seasonal sunlight hours.

Only brief shoulder weeks feel good; most months push us indoors due to muggy, icy, or stormy conditions. Seasonal Weather at 3/10 and Environment at 6/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for pleasant weather windows.

Poverty traps are entrenched; eviction, food insecurity, and unsafe neighborhoods are common outcomes. Minimum Wage at 1/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Childcare Support (Citizens) at 4/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for quality of life – lower-income tier.

Quality of life is compromised—overwork and cramped housing become normal to cover basics. Typical Software Salaries at 1/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Work-Life Balance at 4/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.

Luxury services are thin; wealth management and elite schooling often require another city. Housing Situation at 3/10, Private Education at 2/10, and Family Life at 6/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Spacious rentals are rare; we likely settle for smaller homes or relocate to a different metro. Housing Situation at 3/10 and Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

Opportunities are sporadic; we rely on informal networks or satellite towns to join community living models. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 4/10, and Family Life at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for community living opportunities.

Surface politeness exists yet deeper support systems take sustained effort to unlock. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 4/10, and Common Hobbies at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for friendliness & neighborliness index.

Harassment and exclusionary politics pose safety and stability risks. Welcoming of US Migrants at 1/10, Progressivism at 3/10, and Language & English Ubiquity at 3/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for immigrant sentiment – general.

Hostility or exclusionary policies make us feel unwelcome despite best efforts. Welcoming of US Migrants at 1/10, Language & English Ubiquity at 3/10, and View of Them by Neighboring Countries at 4/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for immigrant sentiment – white migrants.

Friendly exchanges happen when we initiate; staff and strangers respond positively. Community Vibes at 7/10, Nightlife Culture at 8/10, and Common Hobbies at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for surface interaction norms.

Social circles are slow to open; we need persistence and shared projects to connect deeply. Community Vibes at 7/10, Meetups & Communities at 4/10, and What Is Intriguing at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for depth-seeking social norms.

Personal space is often compressed, so we must advocate gently for comfort. Community Vibes at 7/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 5/10, and View of self at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for personal boundary & bubble norms.

Speaking openly risks social penalties, so most issues stay hidden. Progressivism at 3/10, What Is Intriguing at 8/10, and Trust in Government at 3/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for moral, honesty & openness expectations.

Beauty investments run high; opting out draws comments or limits opportunities. Fashion Trends (Male) at 5/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for grooming & beauty investment.

Visible pressure to stay slim or athletic influences work and school culture. Fashion Trends (Male) at 5/10, Fashion Trends (Female) at 5/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for body image & fitness pressure.

Trend cycles move fast; failing to keep up draws comments or limits networking. Fashion Trends (Male) at 5/10 and Fashion Trends (Female) at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for fashion & style expectations.

Mixed norms—some groups embrace consent while others rely on outdated assumptions. Sex (Attitudes) at 5/10, LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 5/10, and Nightlife Culture at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for flirting boundaries & consent culture.

Rigid gender expectations create discomfort for progressive or queer expressions. Gender Roles at 4/10, Gender Fluidity at 3/10, and Sex (Attitudes) at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for gendered flirting expectations.

Families risk stigma or legal complications when open about their structure. Polyamory at 2/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 5/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for monogamy vs. non-monogamy acceptance.

Attitudes split; open discussion is fine in urban enclaves yet frowned upon elsewhere. Sex (Attitudes) at 5/10, Nightlife & Music at 9/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Stigma is strong; custody and tenancy agreements become complicated. Polyamory at 2/10, Community Vibes at 7/10, and LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 5/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for group & multi-partner relationship attitudes.

We occasionally experience closer contact than preferred but can steer interactions politely. Community Vibes at 7/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 5/10, and Nightlife Culture at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for personal space & touch norms.

High prevalence of firearms and lax rules elevate daily risk perception. Safety & Crime at 6/10, State Ideology at 2/10, and Political System at 1/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for firearm laws & ownership culture.

Harsh sentencing and moral panic dominate political rhetoric. Progressivism at 3/10, Political System at 1/10, and Safety & Crime at 6/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for controlled substance policies.

Aggressive tactics and profiling are common, eroding trust in authorities. Safety & Crime at 6/10, Progressivism at 3/10, and Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 1/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for drug enforcement climate.
Multiple incidents within the past decade impact how we choose schools and venues. Safety & Crime at 6/10 and Stability at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for mass violence incidence.

Conditions are degrading with widespread labor exploitation and violence. Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 1/10, Safety & Crime at 6/10, and Perceived Corruption at 3/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for carceral conditions & prison labor.

Walking is possible yet stressful due to gaps in sidewalks or aggressive driving. Public Transportation at 4/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Nature Access at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

Public health messaging is uneven; we invest extra time to maintain routines. Healthcare (Citizens) at 5/10, Work-Life Balance at 4/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for community health consciousness.

Maintaining clean eating requires vigilance and possibly specialty stores. Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10, Community Health Consciousness at 5/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for processed food saturation.

We can meet most cravings but specialty ingredients or restaurants appear sporadically. Nightlife & Music at 9/10, Common Hobbies at 8/10, and Meetups & Communities at 4/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for fresh & international cuisine access.

Prevalence is high with long waits and patchy insurance coverage. Seasonal Weather at 3/10, Work-Life Balance at 4/10, and Community Vibes at 7/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for depression prevalence.

Rates continue climbing; youth obesity impacts schools and recreation. Community Health Consciousness at 5/10, Work-Life Balance at 4/10, and Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for obesity rate.

Higher cancer rates tie to environmental or lifestyle factors we must actively mitigate. Environment at 6/10, Healthcare (Citizens) at 5/10, and Community Health Consciousness at 5/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for cancer incidence.

Chronic unemployment or underemployment signals deep structural issues. Economic Health at 2/10, Remote-Friendly Culture at 2/10, and Typical Software Salaries at 1/10 steer the family toward an unsustainable outlook for broader job market resilience.
